description: Maintained by the Faculty of Forestry at the University of British Columbia, the UBC Malcolm Knapp Research Forest was established in 1949 from a Crown grant. The forest is located near Maple Ridge and a section of the park contains well marked trails used by hikers and joggers.There are a variety of trails to hike in the area and it is best to pick up a map at the office building by the gate to the park. The map shows several trails by color and it corresponds with the maps and trail markings throughout the park.All trails are beautiful and feater second growth forest, mossy paths, still marshes, bushy paths, and a variety of local fauna such as dog wood, pine, and cedar along with plenty of birds to watch like finches, chickadees, crows and more.All trails eventually loop back to the back of the Faculty base and parking lot via paved path.To download a PDF map of the trails go to: www.mkrf.forestry.ubc.ca/pdf/Trails%20Map_2006.pdf
directions: Drive to Maple Ridge following Dewdney Trunk Road. Drive to the intersection at 232nd Street. Turn left at the lights at 232nd and continue until Golden Ears Park is on your right. At the roundabout, go straight (take your second right) and then turn right onto Silver Valley Road. Drive to the end of this road where you will arrive at a gate and small parking lot at the entrance to the UBC Malcolm Knapp Research Forest. Parking is free.
title: Malcolm Knapp - Blue Trail
